prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The facts of the individual employment relationship are particularly crucial in determining whether or not an employee may solicit customers.[1] The most important consideration will be the employee's position and relationship to the customers, particularly in light of the business or industry involved.[2] In one case, an intermediary who facilitated a contract was not held to be a fiduciary and the court concluded that information gathered during the process belonged as much to the intermediary, and therefore could not properly be considered confidential to the plaintiff.[3] Usually, the more an employee is directly linked to the customers and the more those customers rely on that employee, the greater the likelihood that customer information will be considered confidential.

A former employee will usually be in a stronger position to compete directly where he or she seeks new business through general advertising and promotional materials rather than actively soliciting the business of specific customers.[4]

The employer has the burden of establishing the link between the former employee and its customers. In S.W. Strange Ltd. v. Mann,[5] the court held that there was no evidence that the employee could influence customers to deal with him following his departure:

[There was] no evidence that the defendant knew or could be expected to know anything regarding the customer's tastes, predilections, business or secrets, or that it would be of the least importance to a customer whether the defendant or some other manager answered the telephone … he could obtain no personal goodwill …

The defendant had a knowledge of the plaintiff's customers and of their creditworthiness which was no doubt of great value to the plaintiff but there is nothing to show that it was of value to the customer or would in the least degree encourage a customer to deal with him as an individual or as an employee in a rival firm.
There also may be no breach if the customer seeks out the employee, even where the employee is a fiduciary.[6]

Where the employer's customers are already well known to competitors and the employee's relationship with the customers is not closely individualized, a former employee will often be free to solicit such customers.[7] It should be noted that there is nothing that prevents an employee from being as “agreeable, attentive and skilful” as he or she is capable of being, even with the ultimate view of obtaining the customer's business if and when the employee sets up business on his or her own.[8] The courts often emphasize the right of the customer to place or continue their business with a person of their choice, and that customers should be free to receive information from all competitive sources.[9] Where it is clear that customers, on their own initiative, do not intend to continue to conduct business with the former employer, courts will be more likely to allow the employee to pursue the business.[10]

On the other hand, B. Love Ltd. v. Bulk Steel & Salvage Ltd.,[11] which relied upon Alberts,[12] held that a former employee must still “refrain from actions contrary to the corporation's best interests”. Courts may permit direct contact by a former employee where it was that employee who brought the customers to the employer's business in the first place.[13]
In 1259695 Ontario Inc. v. Guinchard,[14] the court relied on Stenada Marketing Ltd. v. Nazareno[15] and the decision of Megarry J. in Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd.[16] and concluded:

In the absence of any signed restrictive covenant, and even if there was not a finding of a fiduciary duty, the defendants had a duty of not to act unfairly and further, not to solicit a former employer's customers for a purpose in competition with the former employer's business for a reasonable period following the employee's departure. (See Armstrong and Cox, [2002] O.J. No. 3418) The duty not to act unfairly and not to solicit Upper Canada's customers for a reasonable period is applicable in this case.

A number of factors will be relevant in determining the length of time during which an employee will be restrained from actively soliciting specific customers, including the position held, the circumstances under which the employee departed, the degree to which the identities of customers constitute secret or special information, and the nature of the customer relationships.[17]
